Let $\delta(m,\alpha)$ denote the density of the set of integers which are divisible by some $d\equiv 1\pmod{m}$ with $1<d<\exp(m^\alpha)$. Does there exist some $\beta\in (1,\infty)$ such that\[\lim_{m\to \infty}\delta(m,\alpha)\]is $0$ if $\alpha<\beta$ and $1$ if $\alpha>\beta$?



It is trivial that\[\delta(m,\alpha)<\frac{m^\alpha+1}{m}\to 0\]if $\alpha <1$, and Erd\H{o}s claims in \cite{Er79e} he could prove that the same is true for $\alpha=1$.

This was proved in the affirmative with $\beta=1/\log 2$ by Hall \cite{Ha92}.

See also [696].




References


[Er79e] Erd\H{o}s, Paul, Some unconventional problems in number theory. Ast\'{e}risque (1979), 73-82.

[Ha92] Hall, R. R., On some conjectures of {P}. {E}rd\H{o}s in {A}st\'{e}risque. {I}. J. Number Theory (1992), 313--319.
